Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Market research for unmanned aircraft system imaging of agricultural fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this I-Corps project is to promote the use of drones in agriculture and natural resource commercial endeavors and research. Due to scale, logistics, and lack of rural broadband internet access, there is a surprising lack of data in agriculture and agronomic research. At the same time, farmers and agronomists are in one way or another adapting to precision agriculture crop management and need high-resolution data at the landscape scale. This project will drastically reduce the time needed to generate accurate crop growth metrics from drone imagery, and then act on the information. Development of this project will improve data-driven decision-making in agriculture and agronomic research, including plant breeding and sustainable crop management. Data from our technology can be used for drone-based yield prediction for economic and value-chain applications, with information provided sooner than is available from current methods.

This I-Corps project will reduce the cost and time to analyze unmanned aircraft system imagery of crop fields for quantification of metrics describing crop health, growth, and development, proactively during the season. The technology is software and workflows that use techniques from remote sensing, photogrammetry, and computer vision to automatically extract replicate images of research plots and management zones from raw drone imagery of crop fields, instead of relying on expensive and massive image ortho-mosaics and high-grade GPS measurements for plot extraction and analysis. The innovation can be applied in the field by eliminating the need for internet access or high-performance computers. The innovation also provides custom zoning of metrics, and quality control of the data generated. The innovation is an inexpensive method of high-throughput field phenotyping in the plant sciences. The innovation can contribute significantly to early-season yield prediction for a range of decision-making and forecasting applications. Implementation of regular consideration of growth analysis using inexpensive aerial imagery in the seed industry will improve genetic gain and product placement in precision agriculture management zones. Precision agriculture management will be facilitated by real-time, responsive, high-resolution assessments of crop health. Improved crop modeling and yield predictions are economically valuable to many sectors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Between May 2018 to March 2019 we used the $50K NSF ICorps grant to travel to 20 conferences and trade shows across the US and interview over 200 researchers throughout the agricultural industry including plant breeders, weed scientists, seed/soil treatment researchers, crop consultants, contract researchers, & drone service providers. By asking about the painful parts of their jobs and how they currently deal with them, we aimed to discover opportunities for commercialization of a new drone image processing technology for collecting real-time precision metrics of plant growth and health for outdoor small plot trials without needing internet using low-cost drones that we developed during our research at Purdue University.

Initially, we were focused on plant breeders as this was our primary area of expertise. We assumed that reducing plot data collection times from 24 hours to 10 minutes and reducing hardware expenses from $25K to $2.5K along with the specific output metrics we offered (canopy cover and greenness) would be sufficient to warrant adoption of the technology. These interviews taught us that although data collection time and expense are pains and canopy cover and greenness are of interest, they are not crucial to adoption of the technology. The most crucial factor is whether the technology delivers the most important output metrics of plant growth and health that researchers need on a regular basis. Accordingly, we submitted a project pitch for a Phase 1 NSF SBIR to develop algorithms for delivering additional output metrics requested by researchers such as stand counts, plant height, weed/crop cover, canopy expansion rates, and flowering/maturity dates. Our pitch was approved and we are now working on our full proposal.

We also learned that there are other possible customer segments besides breeders, such as weed scientists and contract researchers, who comprise significant market opportunities and who’s needs are more readily satisfied by our current technology. For example, canopy cover and greenness are metrics commonly used by contract researchers to evaluate the efficacy of new agricultural treatments or products. This gave us the confidence to complete development of our minimum viable software product (the Progeny Windows app) and commercially launch our software on April 3rd, 2019. We have already secured our first two customers (both contract researchers) and we are on our way to securing additional customers, funding, and investment to expand our business and make this technology available to researchers worldwide.
